Issues.Title: Win Forms DataGridView doesn't auto generate columns when items in the bound list are declared the wrong way
Issues.Body:
### Description

Columns in the DataGridView control are not auto generated when data binding if you declare the bound items the "wrong" way.

If the items in the list define property members with getters and setters, columns are created.

If the items in the list define public data members instead, no columns are generated.

### Reproduction Steps

List<T> listOfT = new();
BindingSource bindingSource = new();
bindingSource.DataSource = listOfT;
dataGridView1.AutoGenerateColumns = true;
dataGridView1.DataSource = bindingSource;

=================================

SCENARIO 1

If T is declared as -

public class T
{
    public int Field1 { get; set; }
}

then a column will be auto generated in the DataGridView.

=================================

SCENARIO 2

If T is declared as -

public class T
{
    public int Field1;
}

no columns will be auto generated.

=================================

It took a while to work this one out! I was able to drill down into DataGridView.DataConnection.props and see they were being populated in scenario 1, but not in scenario 2, which then caused no columns to be auto generated. I'm guessing the reflection code that is part of the generation of props is flawed - doesn't generate props for fields defined as in scenario 2.

### Expected behavior

Columns should be auto generated.

### Actual behavior

Columns are not auto generated.

### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

_No response_

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

.NET Framework 4.7.2
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Win Forms DataGridView doesn't auto generate columns when items in the bound list are declared the wrong way" (#8895)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] Inspect or AccessibilityInsights tool's rectangle can't focus on the entire PrintPreviewControl
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET SDK 8.0.100-preview.4.23172.16

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, it repro in .NET 8.0 & 7.0, cannot repro in .NET 6.0 & 5.0 & 3.1.

### Issue description

Inspect or AccessibilityInsights tool's rectangle can't focus on the entire PrintPreviewControl.
**Actual result:**
AccessibilityInsights:
![core=ppc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94418985/227127203-6837b313-65f7-4913-a1f5-14dd3ae58401.png)

Inspect:
![inspect=ppc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94418985/227127242-478beda5-55b4-4c16-9d50-5a9dd4519461.png)

**Expected result:**
AccessibilityInsights:
![frame=ppc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94418985/227127187-9194ea3b-2c77-473e-a0de-0df9ab49230c.png)

Inspect:
![inspect=ppc=fra,](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94418985/227127285-cfdcb424-00fa-4c66-901c-27e93a71a3b4.png)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a winforms core project with a PrintPreviewControl.
2. Build and run.
3. Launch Inspect or Accessibility Insight tool.
4. Focus on the entire PrintPreviewControl.

**More info:**
1. When set PrintPreviewControl TabStop property true or false, all can repro this issue.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] Inspect or AccessibilityInsights tool's rectangle can't focus on the entire PrintPreviewControl" (#8892)

Issues.Title: Add cleaner theory data helpers
Issues.Body:
For some common theory data (such as valid and invalid enum values) the current pattern is really unwieldly. I've added specific attributes for the "common" test data to make discovery and test writing easier.

Also moved some types down to the common test utility assembly. Intent is to make functionality available to all test projects, including the newly arrived System.Drawing.

I'll be iterating some more here.

N/A

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

N/A

### Issue description

<PackageReleaseNotes>Requires Windows 10 or later and .Net 7.0 of later

Issues.Title: Issue involving GetPropertyItem / PropertyItems and Nikon cameras
Issues.Body:
When I attempt to retrieve EXIF tags for either the Artists/Authors (tag 0x013B) or Copyright tag 0x8298) from Nikon cameras, both GetPropertyItem and ProperyItems methods for System.Drawing.Image object fails to retrieve the information.  

I've tried it with both .NET 4.8 and .NET 7.0 with the same results.

GetPropertyItem will throw a "System.ArgumentException", while PropertyItems will just return the other EXIF tags.

I've encountered this issue with photographs taken using Nikon's D850, D5, D6 and Z9 cameras.  I have not encountered this issue with photographs taken with various Canon cameras.

FYI, Windows Explore property displays the information when you examine Properties on the photographs.  Also, I am able to retrieve the information by using Shell32.dll calls.

And FWIW, when you load and then save a photograph from a Nikon camera using either Photoshop or MS Paint, then the GetPropertyItem and PropertyItems methods will work properly.  Both of those apps must correct whatever the precise issue is when they save the image.

I've placed a sample Nikon photograph at https://app.box.com/s/wwltqsks3r24i8ugxb4ztmyh97hd22wn for testing purposes.

Here's a sample GetPropertyItem call that I've simplified down to the bare essentials:

```
   Const EXIF_ArtistName As UInt16 = &H13B

    Dim img As Bitmap
    Dim prop As System.Drawing.Imaging.PropertyItem
    Dim value As String

    img = New Bitmap(fileName)
    prop = img.GetPropertyItem(EXIF_ArtistName)  ' this statement will trigger an exception with a photograph from a Nikon camera
    value = System.Text.Encoding.UTF7.GetString(prop.Value, 0, prop.Len - 1)  ' remove trailing 00H character

```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Issue involving GetPropertyItem / PropertyItems and Nikon cameras" (#8872)

Issues.Title: Servicing:  Repopulate owner HWNDs correctly
Issues.Body:
Porting #8870 
  and
Fixes #8803

When a Form's handle is recreated it looks for child Windows so it can update them with the new handle. The list of child windows was mistakingly storing the parent handle instead of the child handle.

In the reported case, the parent form was created while the child form was still in CreateWindow. After parenting against the child a property was set that caused recreation of the parent's handle. As the handle reparenting logic was broken the child would be left with an invalid parent window handle, causing CreateWindow to return and error and WinForms would throw an unhandled exception.

Issues.Title: Windows Automation RaiseAutomationPropertyChangedEvent throws System.AccessViolationException
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

6.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

Windows Automation RaiseAutomationPropertyChangedEvent method for SelectionPatternIdentifiers.SelectionProperty throws System.AccessViolationException.
No exception is thrown if the AutomationPropertyChangedEvent for SelectionPatternIdentifiers.SelectionProperty values are "null" or "new IRawElementProviderSimple[0]".

### Steps to reproduce

1. Run attached app:
[UiaAccessViolationException6.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11000223/UiaAccessViolationException6.zip)
2. Run "Accessibility Insights For Windows" or similar application
3. Start listening to all events
4. Press button "button1"
5. Observe thrown System.AccessViolationException
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Windows Automation RaiseAutomationPropertyChangedEvent throws System.AccessViolationException" (#8867)
